data.title: Cinema Parrot Disco
data.meta_description: Posts about The Last Unicorn written by table9mutant
data.text:
Happy Birthday (tomorrow) to Jeff Bridges, who will turn 72. But I don‚Äôt post on weekends usually, so here we are a day early!

I really like Jeff Bridges. I think most people do? This is an interesting list as several of his biggest films aren‚Äôt included. That‚Äôs because I‚Äôve either never seen them at all or I just really need to rewatch them, such as Starman. So I‚Äôve listed those at the end. People will also probably roll their eyes at my number one choice but, hey, I like what I like!

I rank these lists based on how much I like the movie itself, not on the performance. He‚Äôs always good, though. Thought he was especially good in Crazy Heart.

I‚Äôve seen quite a few so I‚Äôll rank them all. Here are My Top Ten Jeff Bridges Movies, counting down to my favorite & including all I‚Äôve seen & remember well:

The Rest That I‚Äôve Seen:

18. Kingsman: The Golden Circle

17. Seabiscuit

16. The Vanishing

15. The Little Prince

14. Stick It

13. The Giver

12. King Kong (1976)

11. Bad Times At The El Royale

10. The Big Lebowski (I don‚Äôt love this film but Bridges is good)

9. K-PAX

8. The Fabulous Baker Boys

7. Arlington Road

6. TRON: Legacy (The Daft Punk score for this is amazing!)

5. Crazy Heart

4. Hell Or High Water

3. Iron Man

2. TRON

1. The Last Unicorn

Need To Rewatch:

Starman, Jagged Edge, The Last Picture Show, Blown Away

Not Seen:

Thunderbolt & Lightfoot, Heaven‚Äôs Gate, Against All Odds, Tucker: The Man And His Dream, The Fisher King, Fearless, White Squall, The Mirror Has Two Faces, The Contender, The Men Who Stare At Goats, True Grit, R.I.P.D., Only The Brave

I‚Äôll be posting a list of My Top Ten 2015 Movies (by UK release date) tomorrow but, as always, I also like to do a list of my favorite older films that I watched at home for the first time in the past year. I watch more movies at home in a year than I do in the cinema so it seems silly to ignore them as there are often some great ones that I‚Äôve just seen for the first time.

I keep a full (sadly ranked!) list of what I watch throughout the year HERE and see that I watched 73 films at home in 2015. Yikes! That seems excessive. Well, I‚Äôll admit that I don‚Äôt pay attention to half of them as they‚Äôre playing in the background while I do other stuff (especially those really shitty movies I‚Äôve ranked at the very bottom of the list of 73). But I loved some of them so I‚Äôd like to highlight not just ten but the top fifteen. You should all know by now that I can‚Äôt ever make a top ten list only containing ten things! üòâ But I did manage no ties‚Ä¶

So here are My Top Ten Movies Watched At Home In 2015 counting down to my very favorite (including the next five as honorable mentions). I‚Äôm proud that I‚Äôve managed to review the full Top Ten other than my number one. Hmm‚Ä¶ I really should say something about that one!

Honorable Mentions:

15. Miracle Mile

14. The Taking Of Pelham One Two Three (1974)

13. The Unbelievable Truth

12. Waxwork

11. Ladies And Gentlemen, The Fabulous Stains

Top Ten:

10. eXistenZ

9. Melancholia

8. Short Term 12

7. Dredd

6. We Are The Best!

5. Road House

4. Escape From Alcatraz

3. The Last Unicorn

2. Grave Of The Fireflies

1. Escape From New York

I wanted to keep this list simple so I‚Äôve said nothing about any of these movies. But feel free to discuss them with me in the comments! üôÇ I‚Äôll say it was pretty easy deciding the order for these but I did have a hard time deciding which movie to put at number one for tomorrow‚Äôs list. Number one & two were so close! But I still managed no ties for tomorrow.

Well, it‚Äôs the first Sunday of the month so I thought I‚Äôd review my blog‚Äôs stats for August. It was my biggest month for views in the almost three years since starting my blog, which is cool as it‚Äôs felt like everyone kind of disappeared over this summer. Where is everybody?! Hope you all had lovely summer vacations. üôÇ

Here are the stats I enjoy looking at the most ‚Äì My Top Viewed Posts For August:

Well, My Top Ten Shower & Bath Scenes In Movies post is never going to die ‚Äì I posted that in 2013 & it‚Äôs in my Top Posts every month. Pervs.

What I‚Äôm always happiest about is when I review something slightly more obscure & end up getting a huge response from people who either wish to add how much they love that movie or from people who had never heard of it & are now very interested in seeing it after my (stunningly well-written) review. üòâ

There were two posts like that in August. One was my review for The Last Unicorn, a strange little animated Rankin/Bass film from 1982 that was animated by those who later went on to form my beloved Studio Ghibli. It‚Äôs very of its time & has a totally 70‚Äôs-easy-listening soundtrack with songs by America plus big-name voice talents such as the always cool Christopher Lee as the ‚Äúbaddie‚Äù. It‚Äôs strange & beautiful and lots of bloggers, male & female, stopped by to say how much they love that movie.

The other post that got a lot of attention was My Top Ten Drew Struzan Movie Art Pieces. I love movie poster art & thought Struzan was more of a household name but after I reviewed the excellent documentary about him (review HERE), it was obvious many bloggers weren‚Äôt aware of him. When I did my Top Ten list of his movie art, people became far more interested when they saw just how many iconic posters he created (Back To The Future, various Star Wars special editions, The Thing, etc etc).

Finally, my biggest post of the month (after that old shower/bath post) was My Top Ten Movies With Song Title Titles. I had a lot of fun putting that list together so was very happy to get so many comments on it. I‚Äôm glad I finally got up off my bum & started posting these top ten lists every Thursday. I have a lot of them ‚Äì I just need to get the time to put the posts together each week! I‚Äôll try to keep it up. üôÇ

Now onto the always entertaining (and pervy) Top Search Terms For August:

‚ÄúAlice Eve hot‚Äù AGAIN?! Every damn month that pops up! And I don‚Äôt think a day goes by where I don‚Äôt get at least one view of my old Odd Thomas review & I know it‚Äôs just because the actress in it, Addison Timlin, wears extremely revealing panties. Pervs. But‚Ä¶ Kyle Reese naked?! I wish! Unfortunately, I have no nude photos of Michael Biehn. üòâ

Let‚Äôs see‚Ä¶ Haviland Morris? The popular bitch from Sixteen Candles? Wonder who was searching for her‚Ä¶ Not Jake Ryan! Ha! Interesting that people were looking for current photos of the cast from The Lost Boys & The NeverEnding Story (don‚Äôt click on that ‚Äì you may ruin your childhood looking at Barret Oliver now). Looking at those posts, I‚Äôd forgotten I did this Lost Boys haiku. I like it!:

Two Coreys defeat

Santa Carla vampires

Death by stereo

Finally, here are My Top Commenters (hugs!) & New Followers (hello there!):

I can‚Äôt believe it‚Äôs already September. But I must admit that I can‚Äôt wait for this month to finish so that I can start posting nothing but horror movie reviews & other horror-movie-related items through all of October. And I love reading all the horror reviews on other blogs, which is weird as it‚Äôs hardly my favorite genre! I‚Äôve been watching horror films since July to prepare. And, man ‚Äì have they sucked! I‚Äôm hoping to watch a few good ones by October. So far, this is the only one I‚Äôve enjoyed in the slightest:

Happy September everyone! üôÇ

The Last Unicorn (1982)

Directed by Jules Bass & Arthur Rankin, Jr.

Based on The Last Unicorn by Peter S. Beagle

Starring: Alan Arkin, Jeff Bridges, Mia Farrow, Tammy Grimes, Robert Klein, Angela Lansbury, Christopher Lee, Keenan Wynn, Paul Frees, Ren√© Auberjonois

Running time: 84 minutes

Plot Synopsis: (via IMDB)

A brave unicorn and a magician fight an evil king who is obsessed with attempting to capture the world‚Äôs unicorns.

My Opinion:

As the parent of a young child but also a movie lover, I‚Äôm often on the lookout for kids‚Äô films that I may actually enjoy as well. I‚Äôve sat through enough crappy movies for kids that I think it‚Äôs okay to sometimes get to watch one that interests me as well. Right?! üòâ Enter the 1982 film The Last Unicorn which, apparently, is something of a cult classic, has a very high IMDB rating (for its age & the fact it‚Äôs animated) of 7.5/10, AND it‚Äôs from RANKIN/BASS plus the animators who went on to form STUDIO GHIBLI yet I‚Äôd somehow never even heard of it before?!? Holy shit ‚Äì I was all over this thing when I read about it! It sounded like something that couldn‚Äôt be more ME!!! So we got the DVD & for about two months I said to the hubby & kid ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs watch The Last Unicorn!!!!‚Äù until they finally agreed (probably to shut me up).

Wow. The Last Unicorn is a strange one. I kind of sort of loved it. I can see that, if I‚Äôd watched it as a kid, it may now be as special to me as the Rankin/Bass classic Rudolph The Red-Nosed Reindeer. No, it‚Äôs not as good as Rudolph and it certainly doesn‚Äôt beat any of the Miyazaki Studio Ghibli films but there‚Äôs something kind of special & ‚Äúmagical‚Äù about it in the same way I feel there is about the Ghiblis. Hmm‚Ä¶ How should I put this? This movie is so ‚Äú1982‚Äù which, to me, is a great thing while to others it‚Äôll be a bad thing. I‚Äôd only recommend this one to certain people who like things such as Studio Ghibli, Ralph Bakshi‚Äôs work, Heavy Metal (1981), The NeverEnding Story, and‚Ä¶ maybe Labyrinth? I‚Äôm struggling to describe this but if you hate all the things I‚Äôve listed, you should probably steer clear of The Last Unicorn. Oh ‚Äì I‚Äôd also recommend it to any bronies! Bronies would love it.

I can‚Äôt really get into the plot too much and there are pictures I have to avoid posting that would contain massive spoilers. In the movie, a unicorn (voiced by Mia Farrow) discovers she‚Äôs the last unicorn in the world & goes on a journey to find out what happened to the others. She‚Äôs joined along the way by a magician called Schmendrick (voiced by Alan Arkin). Talk about an impressive voice cast, we also have Jeff Bridges as a prince, Angela Lansbury (always a favorite of mine) as a witch, and the amazing Christopher Lee who is of course perfect as the evil king who tries to capture all the unicorns in the world.

This movie has so many things that fantasy lovers will like: magic, wizards, witches, kings & princes, mythical creatures including a harpy and a rather scary, demonic Red Bull, talking butterfiles, etc etc. Oh yeah ‚Äì and a unicorn! I have to say that, although unicorns have come to be seen as a ‚Äúgirl‚Äù thing, this movie is every bit as much for male viewers as for female ‚Äì it‚Äôs not aimed just at one sex. In fact, when I mentioned this on Twitter, the response I got was from adult males saying how great this film is. I can see why it‚Äôs a cult classic ‚Äì it‚Äôs very unusual and the animation is stunning. The story takes a very unexpected turn (the spoiler I‚Äôm avoiding) which I now love but took getting used to at first. It‚Äôs nice to not be able to predict what will happen like you can with most kids‚Äô films!

As I mentioned, I found the animation stunning. I was happy just looking up images of this film to be included in this post. I think I may have to change my work computer‚Äôs wallpaper from My Neighbor Totoro to this!

Yeah, I‚Äôm a mature adult. Give me a break ‚Äì I literally had a big poster of a unicorn jumping over a rainbow over my bed for years as a young girl. God I was girly for a while! Anyway, as I mentioned, the studio responsible for animating this film (Topcraft) were later hired by Hayao Miyazaki to do my other favorite Studio Ghibli movie (along with Totoro), Nausica√§ Of The Valley Of The Wind. The studio‚Äôs main members then formed Studio Ghibli. (Thanks for that info, Wikipedia!). Anyone who has been around here for a while will know what a big fan I am of Ghibli & how much I love Nausica√§ so you can see why I had to see The Last Unicorn after I read about it.

My six-year-old‚Äôs opinion:

I‚Äôve started including my daughter‚Äôs opinion on kids‚Äô movies so that I don‚Äôt appear as some crazy old person rambling on about ‚Äúcartoons‚Äù. So, I‚Äôll include it again this time but I think it‚Äôs pretty obvious by now that this one was more for mommy. üòâ

We watched this a few months ago & the movie held her attention well but she‚Äôs not really mentioned it or asked to see it again. I asked last night what she thought of that Last Unicorn movie we watched & the reply was ‚ÄúIt was better than I thought it would be!‚Äù. lol ‚Äì What does that mean?! I think she was humoring me when she agreed to watch it, then. How sweet! I do think she‚Äôs a little too young for it as some of the themes at the end are too grown-up to fully be understood. There‚Äôs nothing I‚Äôd consider ‚Äúinappropriate‚Äù but it‚Äôs a bit ‚Äúout there‚Äù if your kid doesn‚Äôt like weirdness plus the Red Bull may be too scary for the very young who scare easily. I can see it being one she‚Äôd rediscover & possibly love in two or three years so I‚Äôd maybe recommend it to kids of 8 or so. She does love the young Studio Ghiblis, though, (Ponyo, Kiki‚Äôs Delivery Service & of course My Neighbor Totoro) so she was probably better able to handle any strangeness.

Summary:

Hopefully I‚Äôve given a bit of an idea as to what this movie is like ‚Äì I‚Äôm going to include a clip of the opening at the end of this post to give you a better idea. This is one of those movies I‚Äôm hoping to ‚Äúintroduce‚Äù to people here but it‚Äôs definitely not going to be loved by anyone who isn‚Äôt into this sort of thing or the other films I mentioned in the review. I also think being over 35 & under 10 would help. This is exactly the type of animated movie that obsessive film lovers my age who have young kids look for. I forgot to mention that this movie includes songs by America that are the very definition of late 70s/early 80s ‚Äúeasy listening‚Äù. If you like K-Billy‚Äôs Super Sounds of the Seventies, you may be able to handle this film. Or if you‚Äôre the type to get that reference.

My Rating: 8/10

**I‚Äôm including a clip of the opening of this film to give you an idea what it‚Äôs like. If you can‚Äôt make it past the song by America at 2 1/2 minutes in without gagging, this movie may not be for you‚Ä¶ üòâ
